My one caveat with this video is while proportions are nice for visualizing probability, probability is also used to express uncertainty. In practice, one key part of using Bayesian methods in statistics and machine learning is when priors don't naturally correspond to the percentage of successes when running enough trials/sampling enough data, but instead reflect our beliefs. For instance, consider these two different uses of probability: "I am 50% sure the coin will land on heads in the next trial", and "I am 95% sure the capital of Pennsylvania is Harrisburg". In the first example, the probability arises from proportions. In the second example, the probability arises from a quantification of my uncertainty on a 0 to 1 scale. The rules of probability apply to both, but the second allows us to apply Bayesian methods to a larger class of problems.

Finally it has come to this. I consider this topic to be highly neglected by the educational system, at least when I was talking to one university teacher about this, also when reading some books. But I am willing to do so, if somebody shows me a paper, something serious which I can assign a high probality to be true. Applying Bayes theorem is easy for things one can check out simply by logical reasoning with general knowledge about the world. But when you need hard facts as well as their context, things get blurry and fuzzy. Therefore I conclude that there is an inherent limit to assigning probability to many real-world sitautions. And our brains fail exactly here. They fail to recognize their own limitations and lead us to wrong conclusions. Noone is immune to this. Even the smartest people out there, who teach others, are prone to fallacies. And Bayes theorem is a very powerful tool to show this. From what I observed, people are usually "stuck" with what they learn about the world when they finish their education. But the world changes. Much faster than people notice. And it changes for the better, not for worse. I do not want to get into biology here, but I can imagine why this might have been evolutionary beneficial. I have so many things on my mind now, so many different fields combined, trying to find a way to include a bit of everything relevant. And this is another fundamental limit of knowledge and understanding. The mental capacity of our brains.

The thing about those questions that trip people up is a product of how we educate children. In school when you are asked a question all the relevant information is contained in the question, and rather than thinking critically about the answer we learn to comb the question for clues to the answer the way the test maker wants. Thinking outside the box often gets you marked as wrong. So when you ask what's more likely being a bank teller, or being a bank teller, and being active in the feminist movement. My brain instinctively scans the question for clues, and concludes active in the feminist movement based on how the question is asked. Though if I spent a minute thinking about the question I would have come to the correct conclusion.

To add to the discussions about the "bank teller" vs. "bank teller & active feminist", another way to look at this is that many people would focus on the description of her personality first to infer she's almost certainly an active feminist, as that's the stereotype the question is heavily drawing from. Being a bank teller, in contrast, is just a minor detail for a person with such a background: a job she may have, and an unlikely one at that.

Intuitively then the factors would combine to many people understanding it as VERY likely that she and others like her are active feminists, and if such a persons happens to, at some point, get a job working as a bank teller, that they'd be an active feminist and a bank teller, or not get that job to begin with if it in some way prevented them from being active feminists.

In other words, there's a lot of implicit background implied in this question that slide the priors a lot before the posterior is guessed, and if that background is to be discarded this must be made explicit in the way the question is asked and the options are provided, otherwise people will include those details and reason from them.

When we are asked how likely steve is to be a librarian, the answer we give is really about how likely librarians are to be meek. My preferred way of deriving Bayes' formula when I forget is to use the intersection P(A∩B) as an intermediate step.

Given two events A and B, how likely is B given A? It is equivalent to, how likely am I to be in the intersection of the two given that I know I'm in A? I take the area of the intersection and I renormalize it with the area of A.

P(B|A)=P(A∩B)/P(A)

To get the formula for P(A∩B) I can just switch A and B in the above formula and get the value:

P(A|B)=P(A∩B)/P(B)-->
--> P(A∩B)=P(B)P(A|B)

Substitute and you get Bayes' theorem:

P(B|A)=P(B)P(A|B)/P(A).

To me, the intuitive answer is "rational", conditional on (heh) the phrasing, which implicitly sets the context. Here's my reasoning, for Steve's scenario:

First, the trivial point: the description fits a librarian better. Some arguments:
- "Very little interest in ... the world of reality" - farmers are knee deep into cow shit, you can hardly get more into reality than that ("but that doesn't necessarily mean they have an interest in it" - costly actions signaling).
- An assumption might be that librarians are around people way more often than farmers; in which case, we would more readily apply labels such as "shy", "meek", etc to them; whereas for farmers, absence of evidence (lack of humans around to attest it) is not evidence of absence - in other words, we're probably intuitively less sure of their shyness and meekness (so this is already an apriori information / context ("familiarity") problem). These points apply to a "librarian vs farmer" comparison.

Now, to unpack the context in which the comparison is made.
All considered groups:
- The general populace (population or sample - the "outside"/denominator)
- % of (population or sample) that are librarians
- % of (population or sample) that are farmers

This defines the options for Steve as:
1. Steve is a librarian AND NOT a farmer. (1, 0)
2. Steve is a farmer AND NOT a librarian. (0, 1)
3. Steve is a librarian AND a farmer. (1, 1)
4. Steve is NEITHER a librarian NOR a farmer ("null"). (0, 0)

To me, the question sounds like: "Given Steve, which one is he more likely to be?". This would limit the "population" to Steve and present a binary choice of 1 OR 2, of which 1 fits the description more closely.
In contrast, the Bayesian solution includes the other options (or at least the 4th one, in this case). It seems to answer a different question - akin to: "Which of the two options (groups) has a higher prevalence in the population" (1 / (1 + 2 + 3 + 4)) vs (2 / (1 + 2 + 3 + 4))

So possible answers to the (very good) question of "whether people even think to consider that ratio" might be: "they do not consider it based on the given (assumed) context" (null), or "they exclude it based on the given (assumed) context" (1 -> 0). Changing the phrasing seems to shift the results to the "expected" ones. This might indicate that people make different choices based on perceived LACK of information; they "add in" context differently based on how much is missing. It is possible that this process is non-linear, so that having 50% of the context (and assuming the rest) leads to an entirely different answer than having 75% of the context; different methods of evaluations (e.g. heuristic vs formal logic) might be involved in the way gaps are filled in at different "stages".

The most likely explanation for the alleged irrationality in the answers given to the question about Steve, and the failure to consider information about the likely ratio of librarians to farmers, lies in the liklihood that many interpret the question in terms of Steve's preference, rather than Steve's actual occupation. Simply, in the first instance, they are answering a different question. True, they are simply asked which occupation is it more likely Steve will be found in, but, in a more or less free society, without any particular impediment to the adoption of either profession, people are assuming that Steve will have developed a preference for the occupation, of the two, the stereotype of which best fits the evidence constituted by the qualitative report on Steve's psychological profile, and then followed through on that preference and realised his choice. Rather than a failure to consider evidence relevant to a question the experimenters interpreted as simply one about probability, the subjects took the question to be a normal (and not disingenuous) use of ordinary language - the most rational course - and so one that included the normal context in which one would normally think about the life and life choices of another. In short, Kahneman and Tvarsky smuggled an unnatural use of language into an ordinary and natural conversation. Unsurprisingly, the answers deviated from what appears to be rational if one quite unnaturally imagines the question was actually just about probability.


The same problem, in different form, is illustrated in the case of Linda. In an ordinary and natural use of language, the framing of the choices- "bank teller", or "bank teller active in feminism", whatever their strict logical content - and therefore their necessary relation of set and subset - actually suggests, in a conversational context, the choices "bankteller not active in feminism" and "bank teller active in feminism". This, quiter obviously, is the most likely explanation for the alleged lapse from rationality here.


This all being said, the examples still works effectively to introduce and motivate an understasnding of Bayes' Theorem, which this video explains extremely well :). The problem is not for Bayes nor probability calculus, but for the psychology of judgement formation. The experiment quite literally proves nothing whatsoever about our normal 'folk' capacity for an appropriate factoring in of probabilistic evidence into our processes of judgement formation. It may be that we, as an organism, or as an organism in a culture, have problems in this regard, but these simple experiments quite literallty illustrate or establish nothing along those lines whatsoever.


By the way, the awarding of the Nobel (Memorial) Prize in Economics to Kahneman for the work both he and Tversky did in the sphere of the non-rational cues to the formation of beliefs and judgements is, rather than an assimilation of this part of Psycholgy to Economics (lending itself to a commercially motivated rebranding as socalled 'freakonomics'), rather, a recognition that Economics simply grinds to an inevitalbe halt at the spurious notions of rational agents and optimisers and that Economists and all of us are beholden to Psychologists, but not only Psychologists, but also to all those whose work bears upon non-rational influence, from gastro-enterologists to hairdressers, an including poets, drunkards, mediocre politicians, those who ice cakes, and, god help us, journalists. My question: would you trust the result of a medical test that is known to be 99.9% accurate, that is, you have only 0.1% chance of false positive or false negative?

Well, let's now put it in the context of a rare illness. Let's assume, the illness is so rare, that only 1 in a million will ever develop it. So, my prior that I have it is 1/1000000. Now, I go to a clinic and run the test, which is super accurate (99.9%). Suppose, I receive positive result. Being a smart mathematician, I apply Bayes theorem and conclude that the chance of me having the illness is close to 0.1%, which is reasonably negligible. So, I effectively discard a medical procedure which is supper accurate.

I understand that example is not extremely valid as doctors usually take into account multiple evidence including symptoms, family history, and plethora of tests. However, I would argue that none of the tests can be 99.9% accurate, rendering even multiple tests not as effective in changing prior belief. So, if we would use Bayes theorem for very rare events, then we would not be able to change our prior.


PS: would be nice to mention frequentist approach as an alternative to deal with such situations. BTW, I don't completely understand frequentist statistics, so I would love to see some nice visual explanations :)

Bayesian inference is very popular as it allows to rationalize meaningless probabilities computed on random priors. Either the posterior depends quite on the prior, and you get BS, or it does not and you don't need Bayesian inference. Bayesian inference is only used when you do not know what to do, and gives a satisfactory feeling of having a method for decision making, with enough maths behind so it does not look completely like you just had a look at your favorite crystal ball. It transforms a completly valid math theorem into a magical philosophical motto. Bayes theorem, on the contrary, allows to compute meaningfull probabilities from well defined ones.
Finally, I find it more easy to remind it from P(A&B)=P(A|B)*P(B)=P(B|A)*P(A) which is so much more obvious when drawn as areas.

11:55 I don't think the change in response has anything to do with word choice of '40 out of 100' vs '40%', but instead has to do with the way most people are conditioned to answer questions (particularly multiple choice questions).

When you give the choices of "Linda is a Bank Teller" or "Linda is a Bank Teller who is also an active feminish", people are generally conditioned to look for the most accurate answer rather than simply the most likely answer (even if you specifically asked for it). Because of this people will sort of cancel out the bank teller part of both options and instead pick the answer based on the differences in the choices: ie what's more likely, that she's an active feminist or that she is not.

We're generally conditioned to answer questions this way because more often than not in a multiple choice setting there is 1 correct answer and the other answers are considered incorrect, even if they are factually true (ie the bank teller option is only correct if she is not also a feminist).

We're really not used to this type of "obvious" redundancy in choices. As you pointed out obviously the first option HAS to be more likely, as it is a superset of the second, but this is so obvious that we almost naturally dismiss this fact because we intuitively think "this can't be what they're actually asking".

But when you rephrase the question to specifically ask about the distribution of each option people are more likely to give more proper answers because they're now asked to give 2 separate answers instead of trying to pick just 1 'best' answer.

Linda's example... Not sure I agree with your logic there. In normal language, "bank teller" and "Bank teller active in the feminist" movement here are exclusive groups, not a group and subgroup example. In every day language, if you say "what is the odd he is a) something or be b) same something, but with a twist; pick one", what the context tells you is that the groups are distinct, that option A is the set of all "something" except those in option B (hence why you have to pick one over the other and why one is singled out as a distinct option from the former), rather than the super-group to which B belongs - they're as separate groups as farmers and librarians. Compare this to the rephrased question: it eliminates the "pick one" restriction, and doesn't imply exclusivity between the groups. That is the reason why it gets a correct answer, it uses a jargon compatible with everyday language, so question and reading are aligned.


This is not an example of people "intuitively" picking the wrong answer, but the question being asked in a jargon that the people don't speak or have no reason to assume they're being asked in said jargon (i.e. it is a trick question, either unintentionally or dishonestly so). It is just a bad question.

The problem with these characterization exercises is that they have nothing to do with probability, and everything to do with cause and effect. These people being a certain way means they are far more likely to become x over y. The fact that there are far more y's than x's does not change the fact that the person WANTS to become an x. If all they can BE is an x, then it doesnt matter how likely they are to be an x compared to every other letter, because they will only exist inside the x sample space.

The problem with Kahneman and Tversky's question regarding Steve is that their idea of the "rational answer" requires information that is not given. They make the assumption that all respondents believe that farmers vastly outnumber librarians. A person might well believe that the numbers are similar, or even that librarians outnumber farmers, if they've never really had to think much about where their food comes from. Most people who live in a city will ride past more libraries each day than they do farms. In such a case, the common answer is perfectly rational. In order to change that rationality, one would need to add into Evidence the ratio of farmers to librarians. Now we can update our beliefs!

Psychological studies like these, which claim to demonstrate biases or flaws in human thinking but really just reflect the complexity of language and thought, have always bugged me. When asked whether it's more likely that a shy person is a librarian or farmer, they don't interpret it the literal, "logical" way ("a person is picked at random from the world's shy population, with its known distribution of farmers and librarians, are they statistically more likely to be a farmer or librarian?"). Instead they make the perfectly reasonable assumption that what the questioner intends is "which is more characteristic of a shy person, or which is disproportionately likely to be the case for a shy rather than non-shy person?". After all, in everyday life this is probably the more relevant information - people do not ask each other Bayesian riddles on the street!

I've always found it easier to remember Bayes' Theorem without the fraction: P(E)P(H|E) = P(H)P(E|H), which is just a fundamental statement about conditional probability. Using 'A' and 'B' instead of 'H' and 'E' to remove any confusing meanings of "hypothesis" or "evidence", all this arithmetically equivalent equation states is that "The probability of B (if A) and A is equal to the probability of A (if B) and B". That is, it doesn't actually matter what the hypothesis and evidence are, you can shuffle the probabilities around the equals sign as much as you like to solve for whichever you're interested.

There are loads of comments here already objecting to the wording of the Linda question. Please note that this video only gives a brief summary of the results, and the actual study went to great pains to eliminate the possibility that participants were merely mistaking the statement "Linda is a bank teller" to mean "Linda is a bank teller (and not a feminist)."


First off, the original question didn't give only the two options mentioned by Grant here. The original question asked participants to rank EIGHT choices in order of their relative probability, including not only the two Grant mentioned in the video, but also "Linda is a feminist," "Linda is a teacher in an elementary school," "Linda works in a bookstore and takes yoga classes," "Linda is a psychiatric social worker," "Linda is a member of the League of Women Voters," and "Linda is an insurance salesperson."


Among these EIGHT choices, participants consistently ranked "Linda is a bank teller and a feminist" higher than "Linda is a bank teller." But the authors weren't convinced that participants might be misreading things, so they gave participants a subset of FIVE of the eight statements I listed here, eliminating one of the two options "Linda is a bank teller and a feminist" vs. "Linda is a bank teller." Still, even when participants saw only ONE of the two options mentioned by Grant in the video, they consistently ranked "Linda is a bank teller and a feminist" higher in relative probability than "Linda is a bank teller" alone compared to the other options. (And they did other variants specifically to be sure this effect was real. They also tested it on grad students who had taken probability and stats courses and would be familiar with how to compute the probabilities of all of these statements -- and they still saw people ranking the less likely statement higher in probability.)


This study has been repeated in various situations over the years. It's a very well-documented result, known as the "conjunctive fallacy" or similar to the idea of "misleading vividness." To see how it plays out in potentially nefarious ways, consider that it's a common strategy used by trial lawyers. Replace "bank teller" (the less probable thing) with "murderer." Lawyers frequently tell a detailed story that incorporates facts that seem likely about a defendant, thereby making it easier for a jury to believe that the defendant is ALSO a murderer -- because everything else checks out with what they know about the person. Similarly, the description here makes people think it's likely that "Linda is a feminist" and they will rank statements including that supposition higher, regardless of whether you tack on irrelevant and significantly less probable details.

I've seen some people on the internet who are vehemently against falsificationism and champion Bayes Theorem in its place, which as a falsificationist has always bothered me, but the way you emphasize here that Bayes theorem is all about updating beliefs about a preexisting hypothesis and not about coming up with truths out of a vacuum makes it seem to me that it and falsificationism go hand in hand a lot more than those people on the internet want to make it. Falsificationism is also all about updating beliefs about a preexisting hypothesis rather than pullings truths out of a vacuum, and it seems to me following your explanation here that Bayes theorem is all about figuring out which side of a bifurcation of possibilities -- the ones where the hypothesis is true, and the ones where it's false -- is less likely relative to the other, which is entirely in keeping with the main thrust of falsificationism, which is that there is never a way to concretely establish that one particular possibility is the only correct one, only to rule out alternatives to it. Bayes theorem seems to me, following your explanation here, that it "partially rules out" one or the other of two mutually contradictory alternatives, narrowing in on one side of the space of possibilities as the region in which the truth (probably) lies.

In the video he says "People choose option 2 even if the set of bank tellers who are part of the feminist movement is a subset of bank tellers" but the set of bank tellers who are part of the feminist movement and the set of bank tellers who are not part of the feminist movements can be considered as two disjoint sets and in that case Lynda is more likely to be in the first set. Or is it the other way around, because if 0 < P(Lynda is in the feminist movement) < 1 then P(Lynda is a bank teller and in the feminist movement) = P(Lynda is a bank teller)*P(Lynda is in the feminist movement) and since P(Lynda is in the feminist movement) < 1, P(Lynda is a banker and in the feminist movement) < P(Lynda is a banker). So option 1 is correct by the previous line of argument. I realized the mistake I made was in inferring the meaning of the problem. The problem can me rephrased as this -


Lynda definitely is a bank teller. She may or may not be in the feminist movement. Now it becomes obvious that,
P(Lynda is a bank teller) = 1 > P(Lynda is a bank teller)*P(Lynda is in the feminist movement)
or you could also say,
Bank tellers who are not part of the feminist movement is a subset of bank tellers as well. Therefore P(Lynda is a bank teller) = P(Lynda is a bank teller and in the feminist movement) + P(Lynda is a bank teller and not in the feminist movement) which implies that P(Lynda is a bank teller and in the feminist movement) < P(Lynda is a bank teller)


The place where most people make the wrong inference of meaning is that they consider disjoint sets of a super set in place of which one should consider subsets of the super set or vice versa. The claim I made in the first few lines of this comment, i.e to consider "Lynda is a bank teller" as "Lynda is a bank teller and not part of the feminist movement" is the error. The set of bank tellers who are not part of the feminist movement is a subset of the set of bank tellers. So I guess it is a bit unfair that in probability people should say the question should have been rephrased. That is part of solving the problem. The well known Monty Hall problem is a great example of how subtle variations in the questions can alter the answer greatly!

In the case of our bank teller friend Linda, I think linguistic ambiguity, and not irrationality, is responsible for the weird result: Though the answer doesn't explicitly say so, the fact that the second answer is "Linda is a bank teller and is active in the feminist movement" creates the implicit notion that the first response "Linda is a bank teller" means "Linda is a bank teller and is NOT active in the feminist movement". Since the later examples where people were asked to estimate populations of bank tellers and of bank tellers who were active feminists came to rational conclusions, it is my hypothesis that the people conducting the study didn't realize what question the original group was actually answering. If the answers had been "Linda is a bank teller who may or may not be an active feminist" and "Linda is a bank teller and is certainly an active feminist", we might get more rational answers. Better still, if we had three answers ("Linda is a bank teller", "Linda is a bank teller and is NOT an active feminist", and "Linda is a bank teller and an active feminist") that might produce the best results overall, though there is still ambiguity in how people choose to read the meaning of the answers.

I like your point about people being to think more intuitively about proportions.  If you look at the Bayesian Calculator at http://psych.fullerton.edu/mbirnbaum/bayes/BayesCalc.htm you will see two ways to compute Bayes rule -- one with probabilities and the other with 'Odds'.  The 'Odds' approach is much more intuitive as Bayes rule says that the posterior odds equals the prior odds times the likelihood ratio of the evidence given the prior divided by the evidence given the complement of the prior. In your example, you say that gut instinct is that 40% would think the person is a librarian while 10% would think that the person is not a librarian so the likelihood ratio is .4/.1 or 4.  The prior odds was 1 to 20 so multiply 1/20  by 4 and you get 4/20 or 20%

I understand what you're doing, but the initial example is very unintuitive. Once you get to 7:30, you're pretty deep in the weeds. The initial conceit is that one ought to consider a priori the relative density of librarians vs farmers, rather than trying to solve based on criteria. This is not how people naturally think. Yes, you have a point, but it is already a bit of a contrivance. Then you reveal that the error is not really due to not considering the a priori distribution, but that there was seeding in the description meant to bias the result, which is true, however now the example is inconsequential since the things that made it interesting are both revealed to be not germane to what it is you are going to show ... and then the math hammer comes down with notation and long terms. As a student, you would have completely lost me. Not only does the example not require the analysis, but you continually refer to and edit it, and then reveal it is essentially beside the point. There are much better examples that are certainly used often, but that is because they are pretty good; in particular the Monty Hall problem and medical student survey (I think it was Stanford). If you are going to be application-driven, it is best to inform first principles from preponderance of multiple instances.

For the question about Linda, I think it can actually be logical to pick that she is both a bank teller and active in the feminist movement. The problem lies in ambiguity: is one of the choices necessarily correct? If it's implied that one of the options is correct, then the question becomes simply whether or not she is active in the feminist movement, of which option 2 is probably the correct answer. However, if the question is simply "which is more likely," (as said in the video, without the assumption that one of the two options is necessarily correct) then her just being a bank teller is clearly the more logical answer.

Do criminal justice experts apply this to COURTROOM TRIALS? Seems like an excellent application.

The Hypothesis is that the defendant is innocent (innocent until proven guilty in the US). The Evidence is what the lawyers and witnesses present to the jury. So the question that needs answering is "whats the probability that the defendant is innocent (H), given what the lawyers and witnesses say is true (E)?" P(H|E). P(H) is probability the defendant is innocent, P(E) is probability the evidence is true, and P(E|H) is probability evidence is true given the defendant is innocent. And then the jury deliberates and applies Bayes Theorem.

I don't think scientists employ Bayes theorem in deciding which hypothesis is more likely to be true given some evidence. First of all, most people, including scientists, don't reason this way at all. Second, most of the philosophers of statistics, except bayesians, claim you can't assign a probability to a hypothesis. Most of the science use significance tests instead, and I would be lying if I said I've seen papers using Bayes theorem to show a certain scientific hypothesis is better than a competing hypothesis.
I am not saying it can't be used this way, but it's certainly not popular in contemporary science.

I'm told that many medical doctors do not understand Bayes Theorem, and it can be threatening to peoples' health. Example: There is a test for a very rare disease, and the test correctly gives a positive result for 95% of the people who have the disease. Your test comes back positive. What is the probability you have the disease?

Unfortunately, a lot of people, including some MDs think the answer is 95%. The actual probability you have the disease can be much smaller if the false positive rate of the test is high and the fraction of people taking the test who do not have the disease is high.

BTW, when I worked at FICO (the credit scoring company) we used Bayes Theorem so often they gave all of the employees shirts with the formula embroidered on the sleeve.

Most people would automatically ignore the fact that there's more farmers than librarians in the world because they believe this data is outside of the scope of what the question is asking. They think that considering it would introduce an unwanted error in the data being collected.
It's like the question being asked is 1 Dimensional and so the expected answer is too. Giving a 2D answer to a 1D question seems unwanted and wrong even if it's technically more correct. e.g. You could argue that one must also take into account the ratio of alien librarians and alien farmers there might be in the universe. However if everyone tries to answer the question with N+ dimensional answers the results will be meaningless. So everyone automatically applies a limit to make the results align in a meaningful way.

Let's say that probability of being feminist would be 99% and being banker would be 0.1%. Then even when being banker has greater probability, than being banker AND feminist, it is natural to go with option "banker and feminist", because being banker is insignificant for the question. All you could infer is that she is very probably feminist.

comment_text: Ludwig Wittgenstein had a fantastic explanation of probability as just the proportion of possible worlds where a proposition was true to all possible worlds. For example if p and q are the only propositions and they are either true or false then there are 4 possible worlds, one of which is completely described by the proposition “p and q are true,” and so there is a one in four chance of this. Propositions are like functions that take in possible worlds and spit out whether they are true in said world. I think that this is a very similar explanation to that given here which is why I thought of it.

A point on terminology: in Bayesian statistics, evidence is the denominator, P(E), only. Please don't use the term "evidence" for the likelihood. You may be tempted to do so, given (pun intended) that this contains the data under the model , and it is the colloquial term, but data is called just that, data (or observations), in Bayesian statistics.

I think someone may have fallen into a linguistics trap here. Official statistics for how many Librarians there are, are almost certainly based on the official, library-sciences definition of "Librarian" (short version: a position for which a master's degree in library sciences is an absolute requirement; many library systems have more branches than Librarians). But when ordinary people hear the word "librarian", they think "a person who works at a library", including such people as circulation clerks and possibly even shelvers; and there are rather a lot more of those, than official Librarians. I don't think the ratio of farmers to people that the general public thinks of as "librarians" is as high as you imply. Fifty years ago, yes. and then some; but not now, with so many small family farms having gone belly up and sold out to large agribusinesses in the second half of the twentieth century.

Without looking anything up, I would have estimated that there are MORE library workers than farmers, at least in Ohio. This may well be wrong, but it would've been my first guess.

I'm confused by the "Linda" example. Given the description (woman, social activist, concerned with discrimination) and the two options (non-feminist bank teller OR feminist bank teller), I don't understand why it is a fallacy to assume that the description is more likely to fit a feminist than a non-feminist.

The rephrased example that is stated to make it so "nobody makes the error" only adds to my confusion, since it shows numbers that seem (to me) to completely agree with the previous result.

If it is estimated that 8 people who fit the given description are bank tellers, and 5 of the bank tellers are feminists, that means an estimate that 62% of bank tellers who fit the given description are feminists. Thus, by this estimate, it is more likely for Linda to be a feminist bank teller (5/8) than a non-feminist bank teller (3/8). If these are the same estimates being used when answering the first question, option 2 would be correct.

Here's my personal chain of logic so someone can point out where the flaw in my reasoning is.
Given Information
(A) A description that could apply to multiple people, and which does apply to at least one person (Linda).
(B) Binary answer choices that include only bank tellers.
(C) Answer choices that differ by the inclusion or omission of the phrase "is active in the feminist movement".

Reasoning
(1) The proportion of the general population to which the description does not apply is irrelevant to the question, because we are only considering a person who does fit the description.
(2) The proportion of those people who are not bank tellers is irrelevant to the question, because our only answer choices are bank tellers.
(4) The question is thus "in the set of female bank tellers who fit the given description, do you expect a greater proportion to be feminists than non-feminists or vise-versa?"

Reworded Information
(A) A description that could apply to multiple people, and which does apply to at least 100 people.
(B) Answer fields that include only bank tellers.
(C) Answer fields that differ by the inclusion or omission of the phrase "and active in the feminist movement".

Reworded Reasoning
(1) The proportion of the general population to which the description does not apply is irrelevant to the question, because we are only considering a person who does fit the description.
(2) The first question is "what percent of people who fit that description do we expect to be bank tellers?"
(3) The second question is "what percent of that subset do we expect to be feminists?"

If there are two boxes each with 10 red candies and blue candies and you close your eyes and pull out a candy from either of the two boxes and say there is a 50% chance that it is red you are right. If you double the number of each candy in one box and do the same thing (pull out a candy by closing your eye and say there is a 50% chance it is red) you will be right again. However if you add 5 blue candies to one of the boxes and pull out one candy and say there is a 50% chance of it being red you'll be wrong. There is a slight decrease in chance that it will be red because by adding blue candies you have decrease the overall ratio of red candies to blue candies so the probability that your hypothesis, given the evidence, is true has decreased slightly. This is an amazing video, but I'd like to point out that human speech doesn't occur in a vacuum. More specifically, people give answers that are useful to the addressee more often than answers that are technically true; after all, that's why people communicate (think: 'there's a shovel in the shed if it snows'; does the shovel cease to exist if it doesn't?). In the case of Linda, for example, it is more useful to say that Lind is a bank teller who is involved in the feminist movement (assuming that her description matches being a feminist more than not), given that the addressee seems to know, or at least have assumed, that Linda is a bank-teller already (answering that Linda is not a bank teller is not an option). Again, this video was amazing, but I think it's worth pointing out that a large and useful(!) part of human communication does not hinge on mathematical truth but on interspeaker convenience and we really shouldn't strive to 'correct' human judgments or label them as necessarily wrong.

11:05 bugs me, because "or" in normally spoken language is usually interpreted as an "exclusive or". And in order to make these questions exclusive, you implicitly assume, that the first question is only the set of people that do NOT have the additional description. And then it is not a subset anymore. And an "or" is especially assumed as exclusive in the context of getting offered two options. So I don't think it is fair to frame it as completely irrational. Because it has rational implicit assumptions behind it, that make sense.


And when you ask "how many are:...?" you won't assume this exclusivity, so everyone answers this as expected. So I don't think this proves any irrationality.
